email.title: Weekly Digest

image.alt: Picture of a cup of tea with two cigarette biscuits leaning against the tea plate
image.title: Cigarettes Russes

email.text:
Hi everyone! Here's yet another digest.
We hope you enjoyed our events this past week and thank you for coming. We have many more industrial events planned this month, as well as our first social event of the year - the Welcome Bar Night! Read on for more information!
To reiterate from the last digest, all of our industrial events are catered (usually with pizza). If you have any dietary requirements and if you are planning on attending an event, please make sure you [get in touch](mailto:docsoc@imperial.ac.uk) at least two days before the event to tell us. And please don't forget to **RSVP to the events you plan to attend by hitting Going on the Facebook event**!
email.heading: Careers Service Pi-metrics & Online Assessments

event.text: Many companies use online assessments and games as part of their recruitment process; these are often called pi-metrics or pymetrics (short for psychometrics). The formats vary but the underlying principles are the same. Come along to this session to find out how to prepare and hopefully pass them!

email.heading: Sponsors' Portal
email.text:
Searching for internships or placements? Check out our Sponsors Portal, where you can find out more details about our sponsors, read their blog posts and see their open internship/placement positions. You can also upload your CV and directly apply to all of our Gold and Silver tier sponsors!
You can access the portal at: https://portal.docsoc.co.uk/
email.heading: CV Tutorial by Nic Prettejohn, a former Computing student

event.text:
CV is a great chance to make a good impression on a potential employer as it is the first thing they receive from you. That is why it is important to put enough time and effort into perfecting your resume.
Join us at the CV Tutorial talk where you will be given tips and tricks on how to write a resume that reflects all your relevant skills and abilities for a software engineering internship/job. You will also have a chance to ask any questions from our speaker at the end of the event.
The talk will be hosted by Nic Prettejohn who graduated from Imperial with a BEng in Computing in 2016 and was the former DoCSoc President.

email.heading: Welcome Bar Night

event.text:
It's time for DoCSoc's first bar night of the year: The Welcome Bar Night!
Come along for free drinks and to say hi to our new freshers or catch up with friends - it's sure to be a night you don't want to miss out on.
Two drinks tokens will be given upon entry for FREE to all DoCSoc members.
We may decide to head to Belushi's after the event; if this is the case, DoCSoc often buys attendees a round of drinks, so if you're unable to come to the bar night, bear in mind there is still a chance members will go out after!
----------------------
You must be a member of DoCSoc by Friday 18th October in order to be admitted. Computing, JMC, and EIE students are automatically members of DoCSoc. Membership is £30. Strictly 18+ only - we will be checking IDs.
Please send an email to us at docsoc@ic.ac.uk if you intend to bring a non-Imperial plus one. Any Imperial plus-ones must have purchased membership, otherwise they will be denied entry.
Our full barnight policy is linked here: http://docsoc.co.uk/barnightpolicy
Find out more: http://docsoc.co.uk/join

email.heading: Microsoft - Fast, Fuzzy Prefix Search

event.text:
Daniel Slocombe from Microsoft will talk about People and Entity search in Outlook and Exchange.
He will explain some the problems faced, and techniques used to solve, online spell correction and fuzzy lookup with experience from serving billions of requests a week.
This event will be catered with free pizza and soft drinks as usual! Please press GOING to help us gauge our food ordering requirements. If you have any specific dietary requirements, please let us know a few days beforehand by emailing docsoc@imperial.ac.uk
_______
You must be a member of DoCSoc on the day of the event in order to participate. Computing, JMC, and EIE students are automatically DoCSoc members. Membership can be purchased for £30 at docsoc.co.uk/join.

email.heading: Bloomberg - The Soul of the Beast

event.text:
What makes Python so easy to learn and read? Other languages also have a robust community and a compelling ecosystem and standard library, but Python somehow stands out on how easy it is to understand existing code and how quickly and pleasantly people can learn it. In this talk, we learn everything about the Python Grammar: - How the Python parser is automatically generated and how it works - How the technical details of the grammar translate into the properties of the language we all know and love - What are the limitations that prevent some grammar rules you would think are trivial from being implement - And finally, how to include new grammar rules in CPython in the form of a new operator with an associated protocol.
This event will be catered with free pizza and soft drinks as usual! Please press GOING to help us gauge our food ordering requirements. If you have any specific dietary requirements, please let us know a few days beforehand by emailing docsoc@imperial.ac.uk
_______
You must be a member of DoCSoc on the day of the event in order to participate. Computing, JMC, and EIE students are automatically DoCSoc members. Membership can be purchased for £30 at docsoc.co.uk/join.

email.heading: Reading Groups by Nuri Cingillioglu and Dr. Antoine Cully

event.text:
We are happy to announce that the Reading Groups are back! Reading Groups are lectures/panels where researchers talk about their current work, aimed at final and penultimate year undergraduate, as well as and postgraduate students. Our main goal for organising such talks is to expose students to different types of research in Computer Science. Our first 2 Reading Groups will be by Nuri Cingillioglu and Dr. Antoine Cully.
Reading Group by Nuri Cingillioglu 1 - 1.30pm
Title: Computational Neuro-Symbolic Reasoning and how machines can learn elements of logical thinking
Abstract: "Can machines think?" - asked Alan Turing in his 1950 seminal paper "Computing Machinery and Intelligence". Recent advances in deep learning are yielding great results across practical applications such as natural language processing, image recognition and reinforcement learning; however, how machines can incorporate elements of logical thought and learn to reason are open to research. Combining machine learning with logic-based expert systems in order to get the best of both worlds are becoming increasingly more popular. In this talk, I’ll give a brief overview of my involvement in the field of neuro-symbolic reasoning and discuss how the future of Artificial Thought is evolving.
Reading Group by Dr. Antoine Cully 1.30 - 2pm
Title: Creative Learning algorithms for Resilient Robots
Abstract: Reinforcement learning algorithms are tightly linked with the optimisation of functions to find the best solution according to one or several objectives. Recently, we developed a new family of optimisation algorithms, named Quality-Diversity optimisation, that contrasts with classic algorithms. Instead of searching for a single solution, Quality-Diversity algorithms are searching for a large collection of both diverse and high-performing solutions. With this approach, robots are capable of finding creative solutions to overcome complicated situations, like loss of a leg. During this seminar, I will show several examples of applications of these algorithms.

email.heading: Next Jump Application Deadline
email.sponsor:
\ Next Jump is hiring!
Next Jump is a ‘Deliberately Developmental Organisation’, on a mission to create high-performing workplace cultures across the globe. People development is at the heart of everything we do, and we follow this simple mantra: Better Me + Better You = Better Us. Next Jumpers train and improve themselves at work (Better Me) and use that knowledge to help others (Better You): together we create a better world (Better Us).
With offices in New York, Boston, San Francisco and London, our cutting-edge e-commerce platform is used by 30 million employees across Fortune 1000 companies and generates $3 billion in sales every year. This fuels our social movement: changing workplace culture. We run immersive ‘Leadership Academies’ for C-suite leaders across all industries, such as, GCHQ, RBS and JP Morgan Chase, to help them build adaptive learning teams. We are rapidly scaling our HR technology to large organisations, with the help of a $10 million contract with the US Navy.
As our core and social businesses continue to grow exponentially, we are looking for individuals, who are driven and willing to learn, to join us! If you want responsibility and a job that will challenge you and grow you, then Next Jump’s the place for you! We offer 3, 6, and 12-month internships to penultimate-year students, as well as full-time roles to graduates.
The application deadline for our 2nd November Super Saturday (assessment centre) is **midnight this Monday 21st October.**
Make your application here now http://nxj.me/hiring_uk_eng !
email.heading: LSEG - Make your mark at a world-leading financial technology business
email.sponsor:
London Stock Exchange Group (LSE.L) has a long, prestigious heritage that few organisations around the world can rival, dating back to 1698. We have grown to become one of the world’s foremost financial market infrastructure and capital markets groups, and a global leader in new financial technology (FinTech).
Joining the Technology programme at London Stock Exchange Group is a chance to work with the essential systems and platforms that drive the world’s markets. From Artificial Intelligence, to Blockchain and beyond, our technologists are helping to shape the future of financial services technology, improving efficiencies, reducing risk and creating new business models.
Both our graduate and internship programmes offer real responsibility from day one. This means the opportunity to work on critical projects with leading individuals from the world of finance and technology. Underpinning this is a friendly and supportive working environment where work-life balance is both respected and encouraged.
If you have a STEM degree, a passion for technology and are ready for a challenge, we’ll provide roles that will stretch you and enable you to develop your skills and knowledge. Apply before **1 December 2019** to help shape the future of LSEG’s dynamic and growing global technology operation. We recruit on a rolling basis and encourage early application.
**Apply at [lseg.com/graduates](https://lseg.com/graduates)**
email.heading: Future of Blockchain Speaker and Launch Event

event.text:
Join us for the Launch Event of our Blockchain Competition with talks from space leaders: Algorand, Tezos, Near, Atlas, Graph and Oasis.
Future of Blockchain is a 3 month competition to build a project with blockchain. You can either enter/build a startup or answer a technical challenge. Be rewarded with over £100k worth of prizes and potentially receive investment for your idea.
This event will include:
- Talks from our partners: Algorand, Tezos, Atlas, Graph and Oasis
- Information about the competition
- Q/A with the partners about their companies and challenges
- Free Pizza and beer
If you want to enter the Future of Blockchain competition, enter via www.futureofblockchain.co.uk
